\section{Tightness of the Bounds}
\label{sec:tightness}

In this section we discuss the tightness of the bounds on ${\theta^{\text{c}}({\mathcal G})}$ for several families of graphs. In addition, we link the existence of
co-intersection representations of certain complete multipartite graphs that achieve the lower bound with the existence of affine planes.

 
First, for graphs with very small ${\theta_1}$, the upper bound ${\theta^{\text{c}}({\mathcal G})} \leq 1 + {{\theta_1}({\mathcal G})}$
is actually tight. \vspace{-3pt}

\begin{lemma} 
The upper bound ${\theta^{\text{c}}({\mathcal G})} \leq 1 + {{\theta_1}({\mathcal G})}$ stated in Lemma~\ref{lem:upper_bound}
is tight when ${{\theta_1}({\mathcal G})} \leq 3$. \vspace{-3pt}
\end{lemma} 
\begin{proof} 
It is obvious that when ${{\theta_1}({\mathcal G})} \leq 3$, the left-hand side and the right-hand
side of \eqref{eq:sandwiched} are coincide. 
\end{proof} 

Next, we demonstrate that for some simple graphs, the lower bound ${\alpha}{\beta} \geq {\theta_1}({\mathcal G})$
established in Lemma~\ref{lem:lower_bound}
is also sufficient for the existence of an $({\alpha} \mid {\beta})$-CIR. 
As ${\theta_1}$ is known for these graphs, ${\theta^{\text{c}}}$ can be determined explicitly. \vspace{-3pt}

\begin{proposition}
\label{pr:simple_graphs}
If ${\alpha}{\beta} \geq {\theta_1}({\mathcal G})$ then there exists an $({\alpha} \mid {\beta})$-CIR of ${\mathcal G}$
when ${\mathcal G}$ is a star ${\mathcal S}_n$, a path ${\mathcal P}_n$, or a cycle ${\mathcal C}_n$.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}

Suppose that ${\mathcal G} \equiv {\mathcal S}_n$ is a star graph on $n$ vertices. Let ${\mathcal A}$ and ${\mathcal B}$ be two disjoint subsets of features of sizes ${\alpha}$ and ${\beta}$, respectively. 
First, suppose that ${\mathcal G} \equiv {\mathcal S}_n$ and has edges $(1,2),(1,3),\ldots, (1,n)$. 
Since $|{\mathcal A}||{\mathcal B}|\geq n-1={\theta_1}({\mathcal S}_n)$, we can assign distinct pairs $(a,b) \in {\mathcal A}\times {\mathcal B}$
to $n-1$ edges of ${\mathcal S}_n$. For each vertex $v \in \{2,\ldots, n\}$, let
$A_v = \{a_{1,v}\}$, $B_v = \{b_{1,v}\}$, where $\{a_{1,v}\mid b_{1,v}\}$ are the features
assigned to the edge $(1,v)$. Lastly, let $A_1 = {\mathcal A}$ and $B_1 = {\mathcal B}$. 
Then it is straightforward that this is an $({\alpha} \mid {\beta})$-CIR of ${\mathcal S}_n$. 


Next, suppose that ${\mathcal G} \equiv {\mathcal P}_n$ is a path on $n$ vertices and that 
it has edges $(v,v+1)$, $1\leq v < n$. 
Recall that ${\theta_1}({\mathcal P}_n) = n - 1$. 
To simplify the notation, we assume that ${\alpha}{\beta} = {\theta_1}({\mathcal P}_n)=n-1$. The case when we have
strict inequality can be proved in the same manner. Furthermore, let ${\mathcal A} = \{a_1,\ldots,a_{\alpha}\}$, and ${\mathcal B} = \{b_1,\ldots,b_{\beta}\}$.

We describe below an $({\alpha} \mid {\beta})$-CIR of ${\mathcal P}_n$. We first split $n-1$ edges
of ${\mathcal P}_n$ into ${\alpha}$ equal-sized groups, each consisting of precisely ${\beta}$ consecutive
edges. We then assign $\{a_1\mid b_1\},\{a_1\mid b_2\},\ldots,\{a_1\mid b_{\beta}\}$
as features to the first group of ${\beta}$ edges in that order. For the next group of ${\beta}$ edges, 
we assign the sequence of features $\{a_2\mid b_{\beta}\},\{a_2\mid b_{{\beta}-1}\},\ldots,\{a_2\mid b_1\}$. 
For the third group of ${\beta}$ edges, we use the sequence
$\{a_3\mid b_1\},\{a_3\mid b_2\},\ldots,\{a_3\mid b_{\beta}\}$. 
Notice that we use an \emph{increasing} order of indices of $b_j$'s for the first group, 
then a \emph{decreasing} order for the second group, and again an \emph{increasing} order for the
third group. We continue to assign features in this way till the last group of edges.

\end{corollary}

which uses $2\lceil\sqrt{{{\theta_1}({\mathcal G})}}\rceil$ features in total. Hence, 
$\lceil 2\sqrt{{{\theta_1}({\mathcal G})}}\rceil \leq {\theta^{\text{c}}({\mathcal G})} \leq 2\lceil\sqrt{{{\theta_1}({\mathcal G})}}\rceil$, 
which establishes our assertion for stars, paths, and cycles.
\end{proof}

\section{Tightness of the Bounds}
\label{sec:tightness}

In this section we discuss the tightness of the bounds on ${\theta^{\text{c}}({\mathcal G})}$ for several families of graphs. In addition, we link the existence of
co-intersection representations of certain complete multipartite graphs that achieve the lower bound with the existence of affine planes.

 
First, for graphs with very small ${\theta_1}$, the upper bound ${\theta^{\text{c}}({\mathcal G})} \leq 1 + {{\theta_1}({\mathcal G})}$
is actually tight. \vspace{-3pt}

\begin{lemma} 
The upper bound ${\theta^{\text{c}}({\mathcal G})} \leq 1 + {{\theta_1}({\mathcal G})}$ stated in Lemma~\ref{lem:upper_bound}
is tight when ${{\theta_1}({\mathcal G})} \leq 3$. \vspace{-3pt}
\end{lemma} 
\begin{proof} 
It is obvious that when ${{\theta_1}({\mathcal G})} \leq 3$, the left-hand side and the right-hand
side of \eqref{eq:sandwiched} are coincide. 
\end{proof} 

Next, we demonstrate that for some simple graphs, the lower bound ${\alpha}{\beta} \geq {\theta_1}({\mathcal G})$
established in Lemma~\ref{lem:lower_bound}
is also sufficient for the existence of an $({\alpha} \mid {\beta})$-CIR. 
As ${\theta_1}$ is known for these graphs, ${\theta^{\text{c}}}$ can be determined explicitly. \vspace{-3pt}

\begin{proposition}
\label{pr:simple_graphs}
If ${\alpha}{\beta} \geq {\theta_1}({\mathcal G})$ then there exists an $({\alpha} \mid {\beta})$-CIR of ${\mathcal G}$
when ${\mathcal G}$ is a star ${\mathcal S}_n$, a path ${\mathcal P}_n$, or a cycle ${\mathcal C}_n$.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}

Suppose that ${\mathcal G} \equiv {\mathcal S}_n$ is a star graph on $n$ vertices. Let ${\mathcal A}$ and ${\mathcal B}$ be two disjoint subsets of features of sizes ${\alpha}$ and ${\beta}$, respectively. 
First, suppose that ${\mathcal G} \equiv {\mathcal S}_n$ and has edges $(1,2),(1,3),\ldots, (1,n)$. 
Since $|{\mathcal A}||{\mathcal B}|\geq n-1={\theta_1}({\mathcal S}_n)$, we can assign distinct pairs $(a,b) \in {\mathcal A}\times {\mathcal B}$
to $n-1$ edges of ${\mathcal S}_n$. For each vertex $v \in \{2,\ldots, n\}$, let
$A_v = \{a_{1,v}\}$, $B_v = \{b_{1,v}\}$, where $\{a_{1,v}\mid b_{1,v}\}$ are the features
assigned to the edge $(1,v)$. Lastly, let $A_1 = {\mathcal A}$ and $B_1 = {\mathcal B}$. 
Then it is straightforward that this is an $({\alpha} \mid {\beta})$-CIR of ${\mathcal S}_n$. 


Next, suppose that ${\mathcal G} \equiv {\mathcal P}_n$ is a path on $n$ vertices and that 
it has edges $(v,v+1)$, $1\leq v < n$. 
Recall that ${\theta_1}({\mathcal P}_n) = n - 1$. 
To simplify the notation, we assume that ${\alpha}{\beta} = {\theta_1}({\mathcal P}_n)=n-1$. The case when we have
strict inequality can be proved in the same manner. Furthermore, let ${\mathcal A} = \{a_1,\ldots,a_{\alpha}\}$, and ${\mathcal B} = \{b_1,\ldots,b_{\beta}\}$.

We describe below an $({\alpha} \mid {\beta})$-CIR of ${\mathcal P}_n$. We first split $n-1$ edges
of ${\mathcal P}_n$ into ${\alpha}$ equal-sized groups, each consisting of precisely ${\beta}$ consecutive
edges. We then assign $\{a_1\mid b_1\},\{a_1\mid b_2\},\ldots,\{a_1\mid b_{\beta}\}$
as features to the first group of ${\beta}$ edges in that order. For the next group of ${\beta}$ edges, 
we assign the sequence of features $\{a_2\mid b_{\beta}\},\{a_2\mid b_{{\beta}-1}\},\ldots,\{a_2\mid b_1\}$. 
For the third group of ${\beta}$ edges, we use the sequence
$\{a_3\mid b_1\},\{a_3\mid b_2\},\ldots,\{a_3\mid b_{\beta}\}$. 
Notice that we use an \emph{increasing} order of indices of $b_j$'s for the first group, 
then a \emph{decreasing} order for the second group, and again an \emph{increasing} order for the
third group. We continue to assign features in this way till the last group of edges.

The proof for cycles goes almost the same as the proof for paths, except for one extra twist. 
Recall that ${{\theta_1}({\mathcal G})} = n$ if ${\mathcal G} \equiv {\mathcal C}_n$ is a cycle on $n$ vertices.

\begin{corollary}
\label{cr:simple_graphs}
If ${\mathcal G}$ is a star, a path, or a cycle, then
$\lceil 2\sqrt{{{\theta_1}({\mathcal G})}}\rceil \leq {\theta^{\text{c}}({\mathcal G})} \leq 2\lceil\sqrt{{{\theta_1}({\mathcal G})}}\rceil$.  
\end{corollary}
\begin{proof}
By Corollary~\ref{cr:lower_bound}, we have ${\theta^{\text{c}}({\mathcal G})} \geq \lceil 2\sqrt{{{\theta_1}({\mathcal G})}}\rceil$. 
Moreover, by Proposition~\ref{pr:simple_graphs}, if ${\mathcal G}$ is a star, a path, 
or a cycle, then there exists a
$(\lceil\sqrt{{{\theta_1}({\mathcal G})}}\rceil \mid \lceil\sqrt{{{\theta_1}({\mathcal G})}}\rceil)$-CIR of ${\mathcal G}$, 
which uses $2\lceil\sqrt{{{\theta_1}({\mathcal G})}}\rceil$ features in total. Hence, 
$\lceil 2\sqrt{{{\theta_1}({\mathcal G})}}\rceil \leq {\theta^{\text{c}}({\mathcal G})} \leq 2\lceil\sqrt{{{\theta_1}({\mathcal G})}}\rceil$, 
which establishes our assertion for stars, paths, and cycles.
\end{proof}

\begin{lemma} 
\label{lem:degree}
If there exists an $({\alpha}\mid {\beta})$-CIR of a 
triangle-free graph ${\mathcal G} = ({\mathcal V},{\mathcal E})$ where ${\alpha}{\beta}=|{\mathcal E}|$, then

for every $v \in V$. Moreover, if $(u,v) \in {\mathcal E}$, then $|A_u \cap A_v| = 
|B_u \cap B_v| = 1$. 
\end{lemma}
 
\begin{proof} 
Suppose that $\{(A_v,B_v) \colon v \in {\mathcal V}\}$ is an $({\alpha}\mid {\beta})$-CIR of ${\mathcal G}$, where ${\alpha}{\beta} = |{\mathcal E}|$. 
For each edge $(u,v) \in {\mathcal E}$, 
choose an arbitrary feature $a_{u,v} \in A_u \cap A_v$ and an arbitrary feature
$b_{u,v} \in B_u \cap B_v$ and assign the pair $\{a_{u,v}\mid b_{u,v}\}$
to this edge. 

We claim that different edges must have different pairs of features. 
Indeed, if $(u,v)$ and $(u',v')$ are two different edges of ${\mathcal G}$ such that
$a_{u,v} = a_{u',v'}$ and $b_{u,v} = b_{u',v'}$, then these four vertices
$u,v,u',v'$ have a pair of features in common, namely $\{a_{u,v} \mid b_{u,v}\}$. 
This implies that any three distinct vertices among these four must form a triangle in ${\mathcal G}$, which
contradicts our assumption that ${\mathcal G}$ is triangle-free. 
Thus, different edges must be assigned different pairs of features, as claimed.
A consequence of this claim is that for every vertex $v \in {\mathcal V}$, the number of 
pairs of features $\{a\mid b\}$, where $a \in A_v$ and $b \in B_v$, must be 
greater than or equal to the number of edges incident to $v$. In other words,
$|A_v||B_v| \geq \deg(v)$, for every $v \in {\mathcal V}$. 

Moreover, by our assumption, the number of possible pairs of features $\{a\mid b\}$, 
where $a \in {\mathcal A}$ and $b \in {\mathcal B}$, is ${\alpha}{\beta}$, which is the same as
the number of edges. Therefore, each of such pairs of features must be used exactly 
once, as the features of some edge. It is now clear that if $(u,v) \in {\mathcal E}$, then
$|A_u \cap A_v| = 1$ and $|B_u \cap B_v| = 1$. For otherwise, we could replace
the assigned features $\{a_{u,v} \mid b_{u,v}\}$ for $(u,v)$ 
by a different pair of features $\{a'\mid b'\}$, 
where $a' \in A_u \cap A_v$ and $b' \in B_u \cap B_v$. But as proved earlier, 
$\{a'\mid b'\}$ must already be used as features of some other edge $(u',v') \neq (u,v)$. 
That would imply a triangle by some three distinct vertices among $u,v,u'$,
and $v'$, which, again, contradicts our assumption that ${\mathcal G}$ is triangle-free.  

Lastly, suppose by contradiction that $|A_v||B_v| > \deg(v)$ for some $v \in {\mathcal V}$. 
Then there must be a pair of features $\{a \mid b\}$, where $a \in A_v$ and 
$b \in B_v$, that is not assigned to any edge incident to $v$. 
However, as shown earlier, this pair of features $\{a \mid b\}$ must be used
as features of some edge, say $(u,w)$, that is not incident to $v$. Then
$u$, $v$, and $w$ share the common features $a\in {\mathcal A}$ and $b \in {\mathcal B}$ and hence 
must form a triangle in ${\mathcal G}$, which is impossible. Thus, $|A_v||B_v| = \deg(v)$
for every $v \in {\mathcal V}$, as stated. 
\end{proof}

	\item \textbf{Case 2.} There exists one vertex, say
	$u_i$, satisfying $|A_{u_i}|$ = 1, while other vertices in the same part
		have $A_{u_j} = {\mathcal A}$, $j \neq i$. By Lemma~\ref{lem:degree},  
		$|B_{u_i}| = n - 1$ and $|B_{u_j}| = 1$ for $j \neq i$.
		Moreover, as $u_i$ is not adjacent to $u_j$ for $j \neq i$, 
		$B_{u_i} \cap B_{u_j} = \varnothing$. As $|{\mathcal B}| = n$ and $|B_{u_i}| = n - 1$, 
		this implies that $B_{u_j} = {\mathcal B} \setminus B_{u_i}$ for all $j \neq i$. 
		Since $A_{u_j} = {\mathcal A}$ for all $j \neq i$ as well, these $u_j$'s must be 
		all adjacent, which is not true. We obtain a contradiction.
	\item \textbf{Case 3.}  There exist some two vertices, without loss of generality, 
	$u_i$ and $u_j$, which are on the same part of the graph, satisfying 
	$|A_{u_i}| = |A_{u_j}| = 1$. Then by Lemma~\ref{lem:degree}, 
	$|B_{u_i}| = |B_{u_j}| = n - 1$. Since $n > 2$, $B_{u_i} \cap B_{u_j} \neq 
	\varnothing$. Therefore, $A_{u_i} \cap A_{u_j} = \varnothing$.
	Without loss of generality, let $A_{u_i} = \{a_i\}$ and $A_{u_j} = \{a_j\}$. 
	For any $h \in [n] \setminus \{i,j\}$, since $v_h$ is connected to 
	both $u_i$ and $u_j$, we deduce that $\{a_i,a_j\}$ is a subset of both 
	$A_{v_h}$. As $|A_{v_h}| \in \{1,n-1\}$, we deduce that $A_{v_h} = {\mathcal A}$, 
	for all $h \neq i,j$. Then $|B_{v_h}| = 1$ and $B_{v_h} \cap B_{v_k} =\varnothing$
	for every $h \neq k$, $h,k \in [n] \setminus \{i,j\}$. 
	We can set $B_{v_h} = \{b_h\}$ and $B_{v_k} = \{b_k\}$. 
	As $n -1 $ is an odd prime, $n \geq 4$. 
	Therefore, we can choose $h$ and $k$ such that $h, k, i,j$ are distinct.
	
	Since $v_h$ and $v_k$ are not adjacent to $v_i$, 
	and moreover, $A_{v_h} = A_{v_k} = {\mathcal A}$, we deduce that 
	$B_{v_i} \cap \{b_h,b_k\} = \varnothing$. 
	Therefore, $|B_{v_i}| \leq n - 2$. Since $|B_{v_h}| \in \{1,n-1\}$, we deduce
	that $|B_{v_i}| = 1$. Similarly, $|B_{v_j}| = 1$. 
	We can set $B_{v_i} = \{b_i\}$ and $B_{v_j} = \{b_j\}$. 
	For any $r \neq i,j$, since $u_r$ is adjacent to $v_i$ and $v_j$, the set
	$\{b_i,b_j\}$ is a subset of $B_{u_r}$. Therefore, $|B_{u_r}| = n - 1$, 
	and hence, $|A_{u_r}| = 1$, for all $r \in [n]$. 
	By the pigeon hole principle, among the $n$
	vertices $u_1,\ldots,u_n$, there must be two distinct vertices, say $u_r$ and $u_s$, that 
	satisfy $A_{u_r} = A_{u_s}$. Moreover, as $|B_{u_r}| = |B_{u_s}| = n - 1$, 
	we must have $B_{u_r} \cap B_{u_s} \neq \varnothing$ as well.
	We obtain a contradiction, since the Co-Intersection Condition is violated.  
\end{itemize}
Thus, if $n-1$ is an odd prime then ${\theta^{\text{c}}}({\mathcal K}^M_{n,n}) \neq 2n-1$.
Combining this with \eqref{eq:2} and \eqref{eq:KM}, we conclude that ${\theta^{\text{c}}}({\mathcal K}^M_{n,n}) = 2n$
in this case.
\end{proof}

\section{Feature Assignments via SAT Solvers}
\label{sec:SAT}

For arbitrary $\alpha$ and $\beta$, it is an NP-complete problem to determine if 
an $({\alpha},{\beta})$-CIR exists; when ${\beta} = 1$, the problem becomes 
whether there exists an intersection representation that uses ${\alpha}$ features,
which is known to be NP-complete~\cite{Orlin1977}. We discuss below a means of determining
the co-intersection number in a constructive manner, which also results in feature assignments for
the vertices. The idea is to restate the co-intersection problem as a Satisfiability Problem (SAT). 
In the long version of the paper, we will discuss computationally tractable approximation algorithms that
may be used instead of SAT solvers.
